message: I�m the director of The Fruitmarket Gallery
Today I want you to help with a specific strand of Research for the Edinburgh City Council�s Public art research Project.
You will take me on a curated experience involving three works of art; art that is transformative, contentious, and new.
Are you ready to get started?
Please take me to a public work of art that is transformative...
Ok, let me know when we get there.
\What are we looking at? Take a pic and tell me it�s name.\
Martin Creed�s Work No 1059 on the Scotsman steps
Alright, I am gonna ask some deep questions now.
Who or what is this transformative for and why?

OK. Firstly, it�s transformative for the steps. It has literally transformed them from a set of steps that were uneven, smelly, dirty, unsavoury and unsafe into steps that are even, beautiful and a destination for art lovers and seekers after beauty rather than drug takers and rough sleepers (though in my view they are still welcome). Secondly, they are transformative for me - they transform my journey round the city: I go out of my way to use them, and my mood lightens and my day improves when I do. And they are transformative of what people�s idea of art can be: art can be a set of steps that make you think about/enjoy going up and down steps.
Sorry - I covered that before. I meant not just me. I just saw a couple photographing them because they had enjoyed them.
Sorry - I covered that before. I meant not just me. I just saw a couple photographing them because they had enjoyed them.
Sorry - I covered that before. I meant not just me. I just saw a couple photographing them because they had enjoyed them.
Could you please expand on the quality, taste, and appropriateness of this work of art?
Focus on any or all points and take a pic if it helps.
High quality in terms of installation. Very large, hard to do slabs (as opposed to tiles). Every one a different colour (no skimping!).

Quality and subtlety of idea: many people do not realise its an art work - at all, or only half way up or down. It works as an artwork anyway. That�s (in my view) one of the things art should do - exist alongside people, subtlety affecting how they are/move/think in the world.

Quality and subtlety of idea: many people do not realise its an art work - at all, or only half way up or down. It works as an artwork anyway. That�s (in my view) one of the things art should do - exist alongside people, subtlety affecting how they are/move/think in the world.

Quality and subtlety of idea: many people do not realise its an art work - at all, or only half way up or down. It works as an artwork anyway. That�s (in my view) one of the things art should do - exist alongside people, subtlety affecting how they are/move/think in the world.
It�s durational. Not much public art is. You get to interact with it, share its space and time.
It�s durational. Not much public art is. You get to interact with it, share its space and time.
It�s durational. Not much public art is. You get to interact with it, share its space and time.
Could you expand on the context about this work of art?

It�s in the city. It frames /curates views of  the city and introduces people to part of the historic fabric of the city but with something contemporary. It doesn�t lecture you about how the old town relates to the new in terms of levels / it just takes you there.
Would you like to say anything else about this work of art or any issue related?
Tell me about it and take a pic if it helps...
I wish it was kept cleaner. This is a good day but still, look at all the chewing gum.
I like that it offers views from it as well as views of it. (I�d take a picture if I could)
I like that it offers views from it as well as views of it. (I�d take a picture if I could)
I like that it offers views from it as well as views of it. (I�d take a picture if I could)
Please take me to a public work of art that is contentious...
Ok, let me know when we get there.
What�s going on? Take a pic and tell me about it...
Sorry, I was hoping you�d expand on what you mean by contentious.
\What are we looking at? Take a pic and tell me it�s name.\
What makes this work of art contentious? And for whom?

It is contentious for me because although the label and the lights are still here it is not switched on. Therefore it is not here - it�s like a painting removed from its frame or a sculpture stolen from its plinth.

I think it was contentious when first installed because for some people me it was �only� light. The meaning was located in the way it illuminated the stones of an extraordinary bridge and in the changing light. It was about changing light. Some people thought it wasn�t really art. Some people who recognised it as art thought it wasn�t good enough as art.

I think it was contentious when first installed because for some people me it was �only� light. The meaning was located in the way it illuminated the stones of an extraordinary bridge and in the changing light. It was about changing light. Some people thought it wasn�t really art. Some people who recognised it as art thought it wasn�t good enough as art.

I think it was contentious when first installed because for some people me it was �only� light. The meaning was located in the way it illuminated the stones of an extraordinary bridge and in the changing light. It was about changing light. Some people thought it wasn�t really art. Some people who recognised it as art thought it wasn�t good enough as art.
Our research shows contention raises issues of inclusivity and exclusivity... Does this work of art have issues with inclusivity and exclusivity?

I don�t think so. It�s not contentious because it makes people feel in or out of the �know�. It�s more subtle than that: it was contentious when first installed the way all public art can be - it changes something people know. But this work welcomes all opinions, I think.
Similarly contentious works of art have elements of trust and risk. Can you expand on either or both?
Tell me about it and take a pic if it helps...

I like trust and risk: that�s what artists do, take risks. And we trust them and they trust us. Artists and audiences have to trust each other to work together to make meaning, which is a risky business.
Would you like to say anything more about this work of art or any issue related?
Tell me about it and take a pic if it helps...

I�d like to say something about time. About recognising the lifespan of a work. Some things should be temporary, and all things need to be assessed regularly to determine whether the work has degraded so that the meaning is lost (as here) or whether the degradation can be part of the new meaning.
Could you please take me to a public space that could use a new work of art or somewhere where a public work of art could be replaced?
Ok, let me know when we get there.
What are we replacing and why? Please take a pic...

I�m taking a picture of this whole site. It�s fascinating. The big hole where the St James Centre was, the joy of which (the unexpected insight into the city) should be captured somehow, the space outside the cathedral where the Paolozzis were - people love them where they are now so that�s a success - and then these inexplicable giraffes. People like them, but they don�t mean anything in my view, and I would love to think that an artist or artists could be set to work thinking through this site and how art could work within it.
How does this disrupt the space? And who will be affected and why?
It sits alongside a tree, in front of a very ugly building. It gives people a focus for taking selfies. It could do more than that.
Could you list the agencies, parties and individuals that should be involved for placing a work of art here?
An artist. Someone who knows the space and how it is used. Someone who can unlock some money.

Probably not. But I would start with an artist. Or maybe someone who could think of an interesting artist. So a curator and an artist. And they would involve everyone else, from architect and town planner to audience, in the right order.

Probably not. But I would start with an artist. Or maybe someone who could think of an interesting artist. So a curator and an artist. And they would involve everyone else, from architect and town planner to audience, in the right order.

Probably not. But I would start with an artist. Or maybe someone who could think of an interesting artist. So a curator and an artist. And they would involve everyone else, from architect and town planner to audience, in the right order.

Our research shows the process for a public art project can lack transparency for interested parties. Given the place and potentiality for a work of art here, can you imagine what a transparent process would be?
Please give me insight by steps or association and order-of groups involved.

Transparency is an odd word. Artistic processes are not always transparent. But people don�t like feeling hoodwinked. People respond well to the sense that an artist has made something in good faith, with a purpose, in order to improve somewhere. The process needs to make this clear. So, work with an artist who is good at engaging people. Or work with a process (like the 4th plinth, a good model) that people can understand and feel part of.
Well, that�s a lot to think about... Are there any other issues that you would like to address in the context of process?
In this place and process, what expertise does the public have to offer?

Expertise - that depends what expertise they have: everyone is a member of the public (artists too!). As an audience, they have a role and a responsibility to co-author the work, to give it context, meaning, a home.

Just to be clear: the public are not experts. None of us should ever be given what we want. We should be given what we could never dream we could have. Artists can do this. And enlightened commissioners/curators can help them.

Our research indicates particular issues are left out of the conversation when logistics and process take precedent about the use of a public space. Can you reflect on...?
Please explain, add a pic if it helps
Art enhances our lives. Hence, well being
Would you Like to address a different issue?
Please explain, add a pic if it helps
I�m running out of the capacity to type while sitting in the street. But all those issues pertain. Or can do.
Would you like to say anything more about any issues related to our current conversation?
Thank you for your patience and participation But before you return me, do you have anything you would like to underscore or add to the conversation?
That�s all good. You�ve been a great help towards this research....
